title: Chipotle Ketchup
ingredients: 3 dried chipotle peppers; or 3 canned chipotle peppers
2 tablespoons packed light brown sugar; or, more to taste
Salt and black pepper to taste
instructions: Remove the seeds and stems from all the chiles.  Place all the chiles, onion, and garlic in a large saucepan and cover with plenty of water.  Bring the water to a boil over high heat then reduce the heat to low and simmer for about 15 minutes.

Remove the chiles, onion, and garlic from the saucepan with a slotted spoon and place them in a food processor.  Add the brown sugar, cumin, oregano, tomato paste, and one cup of the liquid the chiles were cooked in.  Purée, adding more of the liquid the chiles were cooked in until you reach the consistency of Ketchup, or your individual preferred thickness.  Stop the blender and taste the mixture; add more brown sugar if desired.
Spoon the ketchup into a clean glass container and store in the refrigerator until you are ready to use it.  It keeps for several months.
Remarks:  If you’re concerned that the ketchup might be too spicy use either two, or maybe just one, of each of the chipotle and guajillo chilies called for in the recipe.
Source:  Recipe from Art Blondin’s “Legends of Texas Barbecue Cookbook” included in, “The Barbecue Trail” by Bonnie Walker, Food Section, San Antonio Express News, .
